            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p class="wpml-ls-statics-post_translations wpml-ls">This post is also available in: 
    <span class="wpml-ls-slot-post_translations wpml-ls-item wpml-ls-item-ja wpml-ls-first-item wpml-ls-last-item wpml-ls-item-legacy-post-translations"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.jp/trident-ursa/" class="wpml-ls-link"><span class="wpml-ls-native" lang="ja">日本語</span><span class="wpml-ls-display"><span class="wpml-ls-bracket"> (</span>Japanese<span class="wpml-ls-bracket">)</span></span></a></span></p><h2><a id="post-126209-_tpr49zn7jhzs"></a><strong>Executive Summary</strong></h2>
<p>Since our last blog in early February covering the advanced persistent threat (APT) group <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/gamaredon-primitive-bear-ukraine-update-2021/">Trident Ursa (aka Gamaredon, UAC-0010, Primitive Bear, Shuckworm)</a>, Ukraine and its cyber domain has faced ever-increasing threats from Russia. Trident Ursa is a group <a href="https://ssu.gov.ua/uploads/files/DKIB/Technical%20report%20Armagedon.pdf">attributed by the Security Service of Ukraine</a> to Russia’s Federal Security Service.</p>
<p>As the conflict has continued on the ground and in cyberspace, Trident Ursa has been operating as a dedicated access creator and intelligence gatherer. Trident Ursa remains one of the most pervasive, intrusive, continuously active and focused APTs targeting Ukraine.</p>
<p>Given the ongoing geopolitical situation and the specific target focus of this APT group, Unit 42 researchers continue to actively monitor for indicators of their operations. In doing so, we have mapped out over 500 new domains, 200 samples and other Indicators of Compromise (IoCs) used within the past 10 months that support Trident Ursa’s different phishing and malware purposes.</p>
<p>We are providing this update along with <a href="https://github.com/pan-unit42/iocs/blob/master/Gamaredon/Gamaredon_IoCs_DEC2022.txt">known IoCs</a> to highlight and share our current overall understanding of Trident Ursa’s operations.</p>
<p>While monitoring these domains as well as open source intelligence, we have identified multiple items of note:</p>
<ul>
<li>An unsuccessful attempt to compromise a large petroleum refining company within a NATO member nation on Aug. 30.</li>
<li>An individual who appears to be involved with Trident Ursa threatened to harm a Ukraine-based cybersecurity researcher immediately following the initial invasion.</li>
<li>Multiple shifts in their tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs).</li>
</ul>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Palo Alto Networks customers receive protections against the types of threats discussed in this blog by products including </span><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Cortex XDR</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, </span><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/wildfire"><span style="font-weight: 400;">WildFire</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, </span><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Advanced URL Filtering</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, </span><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-threat-prevention"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Advanced Threat Prevention</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> and </span><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/dns-security"><span style="font-weight: 400;">DNS Security</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscription services for the </span><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/next-generation-firewall"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Next-Generation Firewall</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">.</span></p>
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/russia/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Russia</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, </span><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/ukraine/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Ukraine</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, </span><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/gamaredon/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Gamaredon</span></a><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/sandbox/"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> </span></a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>Trident Ursa APT Group akas</b></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Gamaredon, UAC-0010, Primitive Bear, Shuckworm</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-126209-_q4yt4t8e060w"></a><strong>Targeting Beyond Ukraine</strong></h2>
<p>Traditionally, Trident Ursa has primarily targeted Ukrainian entities with Ukrainian language lures. While this is still the most common scenario for this group, we saw a few instances of them using English language lures. We assess that these samples indicate that Trident Ursa is attempting to boost their intelligence collection and network access against Ukrainian and NATO allies.</p>
<p>In line with these efforts to target allied governments, during a review of their IoCs we identified an unsuccessful attempt to compromise a large petroleum refining company within a NATO member nation on Aug. 30.</p>
<table style="width: 100%; height: 304px;">
<tbody>
<tr style="height: 56px;">
<td style="width: 61.1056%; height: 56px;"><b>SHA256</b></td>
<td style="width: 38.2034%; height: 56px;"><b>Filename</b></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 57px;">
<td style="width: 61.1056%; height: 57px;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">b1bc659006938eb5912832eb8412c609d2d875c001ab411d1b69d343515291b7</span></td>
<td style="width: 38.2034%; height: 57px;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MilitaryassistanceofUkraine.htm</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 57px;">
<td style="width: 61.1056%; height: 57px;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0b63f6e7621421de9968d46de243ef769a343b61597816615222387c45df80ae</span></td>
<td style="width: 38.2034%; height: 57px;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Necessary_military_assistance.rar</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 134px;">
<td style="width: 61.1056%; height: 134px;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">303abc6d8ab41cb00e3e7a2165ecc1e7fb4377ba46a9f4213a05f764567182e5</span></td>
<td style="width: 38.2034%; height: 134px;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">List of necessary things for the provision of military humanitarian assistance to Ukraine.lnk </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">(Note: File bundled in above </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">.<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">rar</span></span><span style="font-weight: 400;">)</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt; color: #999999;"><em>Table 1. English language samples used by Trident Ursa.</em></span></p>
<h2><a id="post-126209-_iwizxp5feoux"></a><strong>Beyond Just Hacking: Open Threats to Cybersecurity Community</strong></h2>
<p>One of our most surprising observations was when an individual named Anton (in Cyrillic, Антон) who appeared to be tied to Trident Ursa threatened a small group of cybersecurity researchers on Twitter, on the same day Russia invaded Ukraine (Feb. 24, 2022). It appears that Anton chose these researchers based on their tweets highlighting Trident Ursa’s IoCs in the days prior to the invasion.</p>
<p>The first tweets (shown in Figure 1) came from Anton (@Anton15001398) as the invasion was underway, to Ukraine-based threat researcher Mikhail Kasimov (@500mk500). In several tweets, he said, “run, i’m coming for you.” Likely figuring his first tweets to Kasimov were too unnoticeable, his last tweet included the #Gamaredon hashtag so it would be more publicly discoverable by other researchers.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126210" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126210" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126210" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/word-image-71.png" alt="Image 1 is a series of three tweets made by Twitter user Anton15001398 targeting Ukrainian-based threat researcher Mikhail Kasimov, whose Twitter account is 500mk500. In the tweets the actor uses the hashtag Gamaredon and tells Mikhail to “run, I’m coming for you.” " width="900" height="194" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126210" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Threatening Mikhail Kasimov.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Later that same day, Anton used a different account (@YumHSh2UdIkz64w) to send Shadow Chaser Group (@ShadowChasing1) and TI Research (@tiresearch1) the ominous message “let's be friends. We do not want to fight, but we do it well!” as shown in Figure 2.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126212" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126212" style="width: 410px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126212" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/word-image-72.png" alt="Image 2 is a screenshot of a tweet made by Twitter user YumHSh2UdIkz64w tagging Shadow Chaser Group’s Twitter account ShadowChasing1) and the TI Research Twitter account tiresearch1 with the message “let's be friends. We do not want to fight, but we do it well!” It uses the hashtag Gamaredon." width="410" height="261" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126212" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Warning away Shadow Chaser Group and TI Research.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Two days later, on Feb. 26, Anton sent his last and most threatening tweet yet (Figure 3). In it, he provides Mikhail Kasimov’s full name, date of birth and address along with the message, “We are already in the city, there is nowhere to run. You had a chance.”</p>
<figure id="attachment_126214" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126214" style="width: 800px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126214" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/word-image-73.png" alt=" Image 3 is a screenshot of a tweet made by Twitter user YumHSh2UdIkz64w targeting Ukrainian-based threat researcher Mikhail Kasimov. He reveals personal information that has been redacted in the screenshot with the message “We are already in the city, there is nowhere to run. You had a chance.” It uses the hashtag Gamaredon. " width="800" height="426" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126214" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Doxing and threatening Mikhail Kasimov (full name, date of birth, and address redacted from the original tweet).</figcaption></figure>
<p>We imagine these direct, threatening communications from this purported Trident Ursa associate were unsettling to the recipients (especially Mikhail Kasimov, a researcher operating from within the war zone). To their credit, the targeted researchers were undaunted, and tweeted additional Trident Ursa IoCs over the weeks following these threats. Kasimov, along with a large number of other researchers from around the world, continues to routinely publish new IoCs for this APT.</p>
<h2><a id="post-126209-_aeerhyd2lwk5"></a><strong>DNS Shenanigans</strong></h2>
<p>Trident Ursa has used <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/fast-flux-101/">fast flux DNS</a> as a way to increase the resilience of their operations, and to make analysis of their infrastructure more difficult for cybersecurity analysts. Infrastructure using fast flux DNS rotates through many IPs daily, using each one for a short time to make IP-based block listing, takedown efforts and forensic analysis difficult.</p>
<p>The use of this technique is the primary reason Unit 42 researchers focus on Trident Ursa’s domains instead of their IPs. Since June 2022, we’ve seen Trident Ursa use several other techniques in addition to fast flux to enhance their operational efficacy.</p>
<p>A number of legitimate tools and services have been used by this threat actor in their operations. Threat actors often abuse, take advantage of or subvert legitimate products for malicious purposes. This does not necessarily imply a flaw or malicious quality to the legitimate product being abused.</p>
<h3><a id="post-126209-_g33d78g041ss"></a>Bypassing DNS Through Legitimate Web Services</h3>
<p>The first example of additional techniques we’ve observed uses legitimate services to query IP assignments for malicious domains. By using these services, Trident Ursa is effectively bypassing DNS and DNS logging for the malicious domains. For example, the sample SHA256 <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">499b56f3809508fc3f06f0d342a330bcced94c040e84843784998f1112c78422</span> calls the legitimate service <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ip-api[.]com</span> to get the IP associated with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">josephine71.alabarda[.]ru</span> through the following URL: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://ip-api[.]com/csv/josephine71.alabarda.ru</span>.</p>
<p>As of the time of writing this post, this process returns the following:</p>
<p><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-126216" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/word-image-74.png" alt="Image 4 is a screenshot of two lines of code. It shows the process of bypassing the DNS and DNS logging." width="800" height="39" /></p>
<p>The malware uses the IP returned through this communication for follow-on communications with the malicious domain. The only DNS query that would show up in logging would be the original request for <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ip-api[.]com</span>.</p>
<h3><a id="post-126209-_3cm3xnyqusni"></a>Bypassing DNS Through a Messaging Service</h3>
<p>In the second example, Trident Ursa uses Telegram Messenger content to look up the latest IP used for command and control (C2). In this way, the actor is attempting to supplement DNS for when targets successfully block malicious domains.</p>
<p>For example, the sample SHA256 <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">3e72981a45dc4bdaa178a3013710873ad90634729ffdd4b2c79c9a3a00f76f43</span> calls to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://t[.]me/s/dracarc</span>. As of Nov. 18, this account (@dracarc) returned the Telegram post <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">==104@248@36@191==</span>. This is converted to the IP <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">104.248.36[.]191</span> and it is used for follow-on communications.</p>
<h3><a id="post-126209-_n76h3ctc4bc"></a>Hiding True IP Assignment Through Separate IPs for Root Domain and Subdomains</h3>
<p>On Nov. 15, we noticed that the Trident Ursa domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">niobiumo[.]ru</span> was assigned to the U.S. Department of Defense Network Information Center IP <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">147.159.180[.]73</span>. We quickly identified that Trident Ursa had no operational control over, or use of, that IP.</p>
<p>Trident Ursa had seeded the fast flux DNS tables for its root domains with “junk” IPs in an attempt to confuse researchers and protect its true operational infrastructure. Instead of using root domains, they were instead using subdomains for their operations.</p>
<p>The true operational IP could only be found by querying DNS upon a subdomain. In this case (shown in Figure 4), querying upon subdomain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">aaa.niobiumo[.]ru</span> returned the operational IP <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">64.227.67[.]175</span>.</p>
<p><figure id="attachment_126218" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126218" style="width: 897px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126218" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/word-image-75.png" alt="Image 4 is a table with columns listing name, class, type, data and time to live of domains, with the domains listed under the “name” column. An arrow points to the operational IP for the subdomain, and another arrow points to the DoD IP assigned for the root domain. " width="897" height="530" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126218" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">reg[.]ru</span> name servers send a fake address for the domain and a real address for the subdomain (note: DNS lookup for <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">aaa.niobium[.]ru</span> as of Nov. 15).</figcaption></figure>We highlight two observations stemming from our analysis of Trident Ursa’s DNS activity:</p>
<ul>
<li>For its operational infrastructure outside of Russia, Trident Ursa has relied primarily on VPS providers located within one of two autonomous systems (AS), AS14061 (DigitalOcean, LLC) and AS20473 (The Constant Company, LLC). Over the past six weeks, of the 122 IP addresses we identified outside of Russia, 63% of them were within AS14061 and 29% were within AS20473. The remainder were located across several AS owned by UAB Cherry Servers.</li>
<li>Over 96% of Trident Ursa’s domains continue to be registered and under the DNS of the Russian company <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">reg[.]ru</span>, a company that – to date – has taken no action to block or deny this malicious infrastructure.</li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="post-126209-_awm5c8jxjbq1"></a><strong>Various Malware Types Used</strong></h2>
<p>Over the past few months, Trident Ursa has relied upon a couple of different tactics to initially compromise victim devices using VBScripts with randomly generated variable names and concatenation of strings for obfuscation. Each of these tactics ultimately rely on the delivery of malicious content through spear phishing.</p>
<p>The first delivery method we will look at uses <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.html</span> files, and the second uses Word documents.</p>
<h3><a id="post-126209-_s7uy118bddtw"></a>Phishing Using HTML Files</h3>
<p>Trident Ursa delivers an <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.html</span> file either as an attachment to their phishing email, or via a link to the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.html file</span> (in an attempt to bypass email threat scanning). They use seemingly benign URLs such as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://state-cip[.]org/arhiv</span>, as shown in Figure 5. This site appears to still be active at the time of writing this post.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126220" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126220" style="width: 765px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126220" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/word-image-76.png" alt="Image 6 is a screenshot of a phishing email with a download button. The download button link uses Trident Ursa. " width="765" height="502" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126220" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Example of phishing email with link used by Trident Ursa.</figcaption></figure>
<p>These <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.html</span> files contain Base64-encoded <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.rar</span> archives that in turn contain a malicious <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.lnk</span> file. Once a user clicks on these <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.lnk</span> files, they use the Microsoft HTML Application (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mshta.exe</span>) to download additional files via URL, as shown in Figure 6.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126222" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126222" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126222" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/word-image-77.png" alt="Image 7 is a diagram showing the exploitation path for phishing using malicious .lnk files. It begins with phishing and ends with VBScripts." width="900" height="600" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126222" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Exploitation path for phishing using malicious <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.lnk</span> files.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Taking a deeper look into recent <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.lnk</span> file SHA256 <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0d51b90457c85a0baa6304e1ffef2c3ea5dab3b9d27099551eef60389a34a89b</span>, we see that the file is 99.8 KB, which is approximately 98 KB larger than your average <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.lnk</span> file.</p>
<p>Based on our review of these larger than expected <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.lnk</span> files used by Trident Ursa, the file contains random 10-character strings that we assess were appended during the creation process. These are used to confuse analysis, and they have no purpose we can identify for Trident Ursa’s operations.</p>
<p>Once opened, this .<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">lnk</span> shortcut uses <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mshta.exe</span> to contact <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://admou[.]org/29.11_mou/presented.rtf</span> via a command line argument.</p>
<p>Trident Ursa appears to be using various techniques to limit who can access this URL. As other researchers have highlighted, Trident Ursa appears to be using geoblocking in order to limit downloads of this file to specific geographic locations.</p>
<p>In this case, we assess the ability to download <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">presented.rtf</span> via this URL is limited to Ukraine. There are some exceptions to this, however.</p>
<p>It appears that these threat actors are currently trying to stymie threat researchers by blocking ExpressVPN and NordVPN nodes within Ukraine. In addition, it appears that the actor is potentially conducting additional filtering to further control access to payloads. For example, VirusTotal receives an HTTP status code of 200, indicating success when requesting the above URL, but the overall content length of the reply is 0 bytes.</p>
<p>If the filtering conditions are met, the target downloads <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">presented.rtf</span> (SHA256 <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">3990c6e9522e11b30354090cd919258aabef599de26fc4177397b59abaf395c3</span>) upon opening the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.lnk</span>. The <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">presented.rtf</span> file is actually an HTA file that contains VBScript code.</p>
<p>This HTA file decodes two embedded Base64-encoded VBScripts, one of which it will save to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">%USERPROFILE%\josephine</span>, and the other it runs using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Execute</span>. The VBScript decoded and executed by the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">presented.rtf</span> file is responsible for adding persistence by running the VBScript saved to the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">josephine</span> file each time the user logs in. The VBScript file saved to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">josephine</span> is the payload at the end of this installation process.</p>
<p>The first VBScript responsible for enabling persistent access to the system does so by creating a Windows scheduled task and a registry key, both of which are common Trident Ursa techniques. This script creates a new scheduled task named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Filmora.Complete</span> that runs the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">josephine</span> script every five minutes, as shown in the scheduled task information displayed in Figure 7.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126224" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126224" style="width: 829px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126224" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/word-image-78.png" alt="Image 8 is a screenshot of the Command Prompt interface demonstrating how the VBscript creates a scheduled task, which runs the josephine script. " width="829" height="532" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126224" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Filmora.Complete</span> scheduled task used to run payload every five minutes.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The script also creates an autorun registry key to automatically run the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">josephine</span> VBScript when the user logs in. Figure 8 shows the autorun registry key named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">telemetry</span> added to the system to run the VBScript at user login.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126226" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126226" style="width: 753px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126226" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/word-image-79.png" alt="Image 9 is a screenshot of the Command Prompt interface showing the autorun registry key added to the system, named telemetry, and where it was added to the system to run the VBScript at user login." width="753" height="127" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126226" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Autorun registry key used to run VBScript at user login.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">josephine</span> script acts as the functional code of the backdoor, which allows the threat actors to run additional VBScript code supplied by a C2 server. The script contains two different methods to determine the IP address of its C2 server, with which it communicates directly.</p>
<p>The first method involves pinging the domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">THEN&lt;random number&gt;.ua-cip[.]org</span> using the following Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) query and checking the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ProtocolAddress</span> value to determine the C2 IP address:</p>
<p><img decoding="async" width="778" height="48" class="wp-image-126228" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/word-image-80.png" /><br />
If the script is unable to reach this domain, it attempts to access the Telegram URL <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://t[.]me/s/vzloms</span> to get the C2 IP address. It does this by checking the response using a regular expression of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">==([0-9\@]+)==</span>.</p>
<p>After obtaining the C2 IP address, this script will communicate with its C2 by issuing a custom crafted HTTP GET request, as seen in Figure 9. The custom fields modified in the HTTP request include a hardcoded user-agent with the computer name, volume serial number and the string <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">::/.josephine/.</span> appended, as well as a hardcoded string used in the Accept-Language field.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126230" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126230" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126230" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/word-image-81.png" alt="Image 11 is a screenshot of multiple lines of code showing custom HTTP GET request sent to the C2 server. Custom fields have been modified. " width="900" height="203" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126230" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. HTTP request sent to the C2 server.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">josephine</span> script reads the responses to this HTTP request, decodes the Base64 data within the response and executes it as a VBScript. We have not observed an active C2 server providing VBScripts in response to HTTP requests from the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">josephine</span> script.</p>
<h3><a id="post-126209-_ouavjmpic8qk"></a>Phishing Using Word Documents</h3>
<p>The latest phishing documents we’ve seen Trident Ursa use have low detection rates in VirusTotal, likely due to their simplicity. For example, SHA256 <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c22b20cee83b0802792a683ea7af86230288837bb3857c02e242fb6769fa8b0c</span> shows 0/61 detections as of Dec. 8, 2022.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126234" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126234" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-126234" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/word-image-82.png" alt="Image 11 is a screenshot of the VirusTotal software showing the number of detections for SHA 256. In the screenshot, VirusTotal does not flag the file as malicious." width="900" height="171" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126234" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. VirusTotal detections for <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c22b20cee83b0802792a683ea7af86230288837bb3857c02e242fb6769fa8b0c</span>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>This file relates to a purported tender to purchase computer equipment for the National Academy of Security Service of Ukraine. The file contains no malicious code in and of itself. When opened, the file attempts to contact and download its remote template from <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://relax.salary48.minhizo[.]ru/MAIL/gloomily/along.rcs</span>.</p>
<p>This template, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">along.rcs</span> (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">007483ad49d90ac2cabe907eb5b3d7eef6a5473217c83b0fe99d087ee7b3f6b3</span>) is an object linking and embedding (OLE) file that contains a macro that runs the malicious code. The macro itself resembles the VBScript code within the HTA file mentioned above, used to load additional scripts.</p>
<p>The installation VBScript saves the payload VBScript to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">%USERPROFILE%\Downloads\frontier\decisive</span> and creates a scheduled task named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetSynchronization-USA</span> to automatically run this payload every five minutes.</p>
<p>The payload VBScript is the same as the payload above. It attempts to get the C2 IP address via a ping to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">&lt;random number&gt;decisive.hungzo[.]ru</span> and a regular expression on the response from a specific Telegram URL, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://t[.]me/s/templ36</span>.</p>
<p>Once it has the IP address, the script creates an HTTP GET request to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://&lt;IP address of C2&gt;/snhale&lt;random number&gt;/index.html=?&lt;random number&gt;</span> with custom HTTP fields it populates with the following activities:</p>
<ul>
<li>Appending the computer name and volume serial number in the custom user-agent field, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">(windows nt 6.1; win64; x64) applewebkit/537.36 (khtml, like gecko) chrome/90.0.4430.85 safari/537.36</span>, along with the static string <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">;;/.insufficient/</span>.</li>
<li>Using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">frameS5V</span> as the cookie value</li>
<li>Setting the Referrer to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://developer.mozilla[.]org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript</span></li>
<li>Setting Accept-Language to r<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">u-RU,ru;q=0.8,en-US;q=0.6,en;q=0.4</span></li>
<li>Setting Content-Length to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">4649</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Lastly, the script will Base64 encode the response to this URL and attempt to execute it.</p>
<h3><a id="post-126209-_kwk9f3k7n6vn"></a>Recently Seen Droppers</h3>
<p>Over the past three months, we’ve seen Trident Ursa use two different, yet very similar, droppers. The first dropper, usually named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">7ZSfxMod_x86.exe</span>, is the traditional 7-Zip self-extracting (SFX) archive technique the actor has used for years.</p>
<p>In these SFX files, the installation configuration script runs an embedded VBScript using Windows Script Host (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">wscript.exe</span>). The second dropper, usually named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">myfile.exe</span> according to the executable’s <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">RT_VERSION</span> resource, is effectively a loader that drops two files and eventually runs them as VBScript using wscript.</p>
<h4><a id="post-126209-_1s6lv3r2u8pw"></a>7ZSfxMod_x86.exe</h4>
<p>A recent sample (SHA256 <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ac1f3a43447591c67159528d9c4245ce0b93b129845bed9597d1f39f68dbd72f</span>) runs the following installation script when opened:</p>
<p><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-126242 size-full" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/Trident-Ursa-Code-Snip-2.png" alt="Image 11 is many lines of code that show an installation script. " width="718" height="332" /></p>
<p>Along with the installation script, the archive contains a VBScript named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">19698.mov</span> (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">f488bd406f1293f7881dd0ade8d08f2b1358ddaf7c4af4d27d95f6f047339b3a</span>) referenced within the installation script. Similar to the examples above, the VBScript will try two different methods to obtain its C2 location.</p>
<p>First, the script runs a WMI query to ping the C2 domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">&lt;random number&gt;delirium.sohrabt[.]ru</span>. Should this fail, it also includes a second C2 location routine that will reach out to a Telegram page at <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://t[.]me/s/vbs_run14</span>. It then uses a regular expression of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">==([0-9\@]+)==</span> to find an IP address within the response.</p>
<p>The script replaces the "<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">@</span>" characters with a "." within the match of the regex to make an IPV4 address in dot notation, and it writes the resulting IP address to the file <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">%TEMP%\prDK6</span>.</p>
<p>Once it has the IP address, the script creates an HTTP GET request to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://&lt;IP address of C2&gt;/snhale&lt;random number&gt;/index.html=?&lt;random number&gt;</span> with custom HTTP fields it populates with the following activities:</p>
<ul>
<li>Appending the computer name and volume serial number in the custom user-agent field, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mozilla/5.0 (windows nt 6.1; win64; x64) applewebkit/537.36 (khtml, like gecko) chrome/86.0.4240.193 safari/537.36</span>, along with the static string <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">;;/.snventor/.</span></li>
<li>Using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">defective</span> as the cookie value</li>
<li>Setting the Referrer to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://www.unn.com[.]ua/ru/</span></li>
<li>Setting Accept-Language to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ru-RU,ru;q=0.8,en-US;q=0.6,en;q=0.4</span></li>
<li>Setting Content-Length to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">2031</span></li>
</ul>
<p>The script, like the one mentioned above, reads the response to this beacon, decodes the Base64 data within the response and runs the result as a VBScript using the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Execute</span> method. This script also has a backup URL that it will use if it receives an HTTP response status other than 200 or 404, specifically <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://&lt;IP address of C2&gt;/snquiries&lt;random number&gt;/index.html=?&lt;random number&gt;</span>.</p>
<h4><a id="post-126209-_j8xq9tuik8jp"></a>Myfile.exe</h4>
<p>A recent sample (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">a79704074516589c8a6a20abd6a8bcbbcc5a39a5ddbca714fbbf5346d7035f42</span>) works as a loader that drops two files and eventually runs them as VBScripts using the wscript application.</p>
<p>First, the executable reads its own file data and skips to the end of the Portable Executable (PE) file to access the overlay data that was appended to the executable. The executable then decrypts the overlay data in reverse by using XOR on each byte with the byte that precedes it. Using this data, the executable writes the cleartext to the following locations:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\Users\&lt;username&gt;\nutfgqsjs.fjyc</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\Users\&lt;username&gt;\16403.dll</span></li>
</ul>
<p>The binary concatenates some strings to the contents written to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">nutfgqsjs.fjyc</span> before writing this file to disk, specifically lines of VBScript code to delete the initial executable and the two VBScript files. The executable concludes by running the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">nutfgqsjs.fjyc</span> script by calling <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CreateProcessA</span> using the following command line:</p>
<p><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-126251" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/Screen-Shot-2022-12-19-at-4.31.35-PM.png" alt="A screenshot of code showing the command line where the VBScript is running." width="600" height="52" /></p>
<p>The <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">nutfgqsjs.fjyc</span> file is a VBScript file that contains a significant amount of comments that are meant to hide the actual code. This script includes the following functional code that runs the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">16403.dll</span> VBScript:</p>
<p><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-126244 size-full" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/Trident-Ursa-Code-Snip-3.png" alt="A screenshot of multiple lines of code showing the 16403.dll VBScript" width="772" height="263" /></p>
<p>The file <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">16403.dll</span> is another VBScript with the functional code that decodes another VBScript and runs it. After several layers of decoding and replacing text, the ultimate VBScript eventually runs. This final VBScript uses the same techniques described in the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="#post-126209-_s7uy118bddtw">.lnk</a> </span>and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="#post-126209-_1s6lv3r2u8pw">7ZSfxMod_x86.exe</a></span> descriptions above.</p>
<p>First, the script runs a WMI query to ping the C2 domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">morbuso[.]ru</span>. Should this fail, it also includes a second C2 location routine that will reach out to a Telegram page, specifically <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://t[.]me/s/dracarc</span>. As of Nov. 18, this account (@dracarc) returned the following, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">==104@248@36@191==</span>. Using the regular expression of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">==([0-9\@]+)==</span> this is converted to the IP <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">104.248.36[.]191</span> and used for follow-on communications.</p>
<p>The script then creates an HTTP GET request to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://&lt;IPV4&gt;/justly/CRONOS.icn?=Chr</span> with custom HTTP fields it populates with the following activities:</p>
<ul>
<li>Appending the computer name and volume serial number in the custom user-agent field, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mozilla/5.0</span> (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">macintosh</span>; <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">intel mac os x 10_15_3</span>) <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">applewebkit/605.1.15</span> (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">khtml</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">like gecko</span>) <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">version/13.0.5 safari/605.1.15;;</span> along with the static string <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">;;/.justice/</span>.</li>
<li>Using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">jealous</span> as the cookie value</li>
<li>It does not set Referrer in this instance</li>
<li>Setting Accept-Language to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ru-RU,ru;q=0.8,en-US;q=0.6,en;q=0.4</span></li>
<li>Setting Content-Length to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">5537</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Lastly, the script will Base64 encode the response to this URL and attempt to execute it.</p>
<h2><a id="post-126209-_dyzu0g9z3zwx"></a><strong>Conclusion</strong></h2>
<p>Trident Ursa remains an agile and adaptive APT that does not use overly sophisticated or complex techniques in its operations. In most cases, they rely on publicly available tools and scripts – along with a significant amount of obfuscation – as well as routine phishing attempts to successfully execute their operations.</p>
<p>This group’s operations are regularly caught by researchers and government organizations, and yet they don’t seem to care. They simply add additional obfuscation, new domains and new techniques and try again – often even reusing previous samples.</p>
<p>Continuously operating in this way since at least 2014 with no sign of slowing down throughout this period of conflict, Trident Ursa continues to be successful. For all of these reasons, they remain a significant threat to Ukraine, one which Ukraine and its allies need to actively defend against.</p>
<h2><a id="post-126209-_x089wim9p2l3"></a><strong>Protections and Mitigations</strong></h2>
<p>The best defense against Trident Ursa is a security posture that favors prevention. We recommend that organizations implement the following measures:</p>
<ul>
<li>Search network and endpoint logs for any evidence of the indicators of compromise associated with this threat group.</li>
<li>Ensure cybersecurity solutions are effectively blocking against the active infrastructure <a href="https://github.com/pan-unit42/iocs/blob/master/Gamaredon/Gamaredon_IoCs_DEC2022.txt" target="_blank" rel="noopener">IoCs</a>.</li>
<li>Implement a DNS security solution in order to detect and mitigate DNS requests for known C2 infrastructure. In addition, if an organization does not have a specific use case for services such as Telegram Messaging and domain lookup tools within their business environment, add these domains to the organization’s block list or do not add them to the allow list in the case of Zero Trust networks.</li>
<li>Apply additional scrutiny to all network traffic communicating with AS 197695 (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Reg[.]ru</span>).</li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>EMEA: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>APAC: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
</ul>
<p>For Palo Alto Networks customers, our products and services provide the following coverage associated with this campaign:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> customers receive protection at the endpoints from the malware techniques described in this blog.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/wildfire">WildFire</a> cloud-based threat analysis service accurately identifies the malware described in this blog as malicious.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filterin</a>g and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DNS Security</a> identify all phishing and malware domains associated with this group as malicious.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/next-generation-firewall"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Next-Generation Firewalls</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> with an </span><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-threat-prevention"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Advanced Threat Prevention</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> security subscription can block the attacks with Best Practices via Threat Prevention signature 86694.</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings, including file samples and indicators of compromise, with the <a href="https://cert.gov.ua/about-us" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine</a> as well as our fellow <a href="https://cyberthreatalliance.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a> members. These organizations use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors.</p>
<h2><a id="post-126209-_aw4m7qmx0wme"></a><strong>Indicators of Compromise</strong></h2>
<p>A list of the domains, IP addresses and malware hashes is available on the <a href="https://github.com/pan-unit42/iocs/blob/master/Gamaredon/Gamaredon_IoCs_DEC2022.txt">Unit 42 GitHub</a>.</p>
<h2><strong><a id="additionalresources"></a>Additional Resources</strong></h2>
<p><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/gamaredon-primitive-bear-ukraine-update-2021/">Russia’s Gamaredon aka Primitive Bear APT Group Actively Targeting Ukraine (Updated June 22)</a><br />
<a href="https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-60506682">Ukraine in maps: Tracking the war with Russia</a><br />
<a href="https://www.wired.com/story/russia-ukraine-cyberattacks-mandiant/">Russia’s New Cyberwarfare in Ukraine Is Fast, Dirty, and Relentless</a></p>
      
              </div>
              <!--<span class="post__date">Updated 7 June, 2024 at 12:35 PM PDT</span>-->

              <div class="card-media " >

                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Generic-B-1920x900-1-786x368.png" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="Constellation image representing the constellation schema used by Palo Alto Networks Unit 42 to track nation-state and cybercrime threat actor groups" decoding="async" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Generic-B-1920x900-1-786x368.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Generic-B-1920x900-1-1493x700.png 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Generic-B-1920x900-1-768x360.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Generic-B-1920x900-1-1536x720.png 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Generic-B-1920x900-1.png 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="trident-ursa:related-resources:Threat Actor Groups Tracked by Palo Alto Networks Unit 42:Threat Actor Groups"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/threat-actor-groups.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Actor Groups</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/threat-actor-groups-tracked-by-palo-alto-networks-unit-42/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="trident-ursa:related-resources:Threat Actor Groups Tracked by Palo Alto Networks Unit 42">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Threat Actor Groups Tracked by Palo Alto Networks Unit 42</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/academic-serpens/" title="Academic Serpens" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="trident-ursa:related-resources:Threat Actor Groups Tracked by Palo Alto Networks Unit 42:Academic Serpens">Academic Serpens</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/agent-serpens/" title="Agent Serpens" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="trident-ursa:related-resources:Threat Actor Groups Tracked by Palo Alto Networks Unit 42:Agent Serpens">Agent Serpens</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/agonizing-serpens/" title="Agonizing Serpens" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="trident-ursa:related-resources:Threat Actor Groups Tracked by Palo Alto Networks Unit 42:Agonizing Serpens">Agonizing Serpens</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/threat-actor-groups-tracked-by-palo-alto-networks-unit-42/" title="Threat Actor Groups Tracked by Palo Alto Networks Unit 42" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="trident-ursa:related-resources:Threat Actor Groups Tracked by Palo Alto Networks Unit 42:read now">
                    Read now                    <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-right-arrow-withtail.svg" alt="Right arrow">
                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>

              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/01_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="A digital image depicting a skull formed by binary code, composed of ones and zeros, in shades of blue against a black background.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="trident-ursa:related-resources:Operation Diplomatic Specter: An Active Chinese Cyberespionage Campaign Leverages Rare Tool Set to Target Governmental Entities in the Middle East, Africa and Asia:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/operation-diplomatic-specter/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="trident-ursa:related-resources:Operation Diplomatic Specter: An Active Chinese Cyberespionage Campaign Leverages Rare Tool Set to Target Governmental Entities in the Middle East, Africa and Asia">

              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="718" height="440" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/PA-Unit42-TAC-FightingURSA_-Landscape-718x440.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="A stylized portrayal of APT Fighting Ursa.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="trident-ursa:related-resources:Fighting Ursa Aka APT28: Illuminating a Covert Campaign:Threat Actor Groups"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/threat-actor-groups.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Actor Groups</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/russian-apt-fighting-ursa-exploits-cve-2023-233397/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="trident-ursa:related-resources:Fighting Ursa Aka APT28: Illuminating a Covert Campaign">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Fighting Ursa Aka APT28: Illuminating a Covert Campaign</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/fighting-ursa/" title="Fighting Ursa" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="trident-ursa:related-resources:Fighting Ursa Aka APT28: Illuminating a Covert Campaign:Fighting Ursa">Fighting Ursa</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/cve-2023-23397/" title="CVE-2023-23397" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="trident-ursa:related-resources:Fighting Ursa Aka APT28: Illuminating a Covert Campaign:CVE-2023-23397">CVE-2023-23397</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/apt28/" title="APT28" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="trident-ursa:related-resources:Fighting Ursa Aka APT28: Illuminating a Covert Campaign:APT28">APT28</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/russian-apt-fighting-ursa-exploits-cve-2023-233397/" title="Fighting Ursa Aka APT28: Illuminating a Covert Campaign" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="trident-ursa:related-resources:Fighting Ursa Aka APT28: Illuminating a Covert Campaign:read now">
                    Read now                    <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-right-arrow-withtail.svg" alt="Right arrow">
                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
                                    </div>
    </div>
    <div class="l-container bs__controls">
      <div class="bs__progress"><span></span></div>
      <div class="bs__navigation"> 
        <ul>
          <li> 
            <button id="prevButton"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/slider-arrow-left.svg" alt="Slider arrow"></button>
          </li>
          <li> 
            <button id="nextButton"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/slider-arrow-left.svg" alt="Slider arrow"></button>
          </li>
        </ul>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>
 
        <div class="be-enlarge-modal" id="enlargedModal">
          <div class="be-enlarge-modal__wrapper"> 
            <figure> 
              <button class="close__modal" id="closeModal">

<!--  Start: Footer subscription form -->
<div class="newsletter">
      <div class="l-container">
        <div class="newsletter__wrapper">
          <div class="image__wrapper"> 
            <picture>
			              	 <source media="(max-width:400px)" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-mobile.webp">
			  			               	 <source media="(max-width:949px)" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-tab.webp">
			  			  			  	<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Revitalized_newsletter-Image-desktop-copy-1.webp" alt="Newsletter">
			              </picture>
          </div>
          <div class="content__wrapper"> 
		    							<span class="pre-title"> 
				<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/palo-alto-logo-small.svg" alt="UNIT 42 Small Logo">
				Get updates from Unit 42			</span>
						           	 <h2>Peace of mind comes from staying ahead of threats. Contact us today.</h2>
			            <form action="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/apps/pan/public/formsubmithandler.submitform.json" method="post" novalidate class="subscribe-form" name="Unit42_Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form">
              <input type="hidden" name="emailFormMask" value="">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formid">
              <input type="hidden" value="531-OCS-018" name="munchkinId">
              <input type="hidden" value="2141" name="lpId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1203" name="programId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formVid">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_optinunit42" value="true">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_opt-in" value="true">
              <div class="form-group"> 
                <label for="newsletter-email"  id="newsletter-email-label">Your Email</label>
                <input type="emal" placeholder="Your Email" name="Email"  class="subscribe-field" id="newsletter-email" aria-labelledby="newsletter-email-label">
                <p class="error-mail mb-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545"></p>
				<p>Subscribe for email updates to all Unit 42 threat research.<br />By submitting this form, you agree to our <a title="Terms of Use" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/terms-of-use" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Terms of Use">Terms of Use</a> and acknowledge our <a title="Privacy Statement" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/privacy" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Privacy Statement">Privacy Statement.</a></p>
                <div class="g-recaptcha" data-expired-callback="captchaExpires" data-callback="captchaComplete" data-sitekey="6Lc5EhgTAAAAAJa-DzE7EeWABasWg4LKv-R3ao6o"></div>
                <p class="error-recaptcha d-none mt-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545">Invalid captcha!</p>
                <button class="l-btn is-disabled" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Get updates from Unit 42:Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form_button"> 
					Subscribe					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/right-arrow.svg" alt="Right Arrow"  class="arrow">
					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-loader.svg" alt="loader" class="loader">
			   </button>
				<div class="form-success-message"></div>
              </div>
            </form>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>

<script>

(function($) {
	// Migrated from the unit42-v5 + Modifications
	var subscribeSuccess = false;
	var email = document.getElementById('newsletter-email');
	var subscription_form = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form');
	var subscription_form_button = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form_button');
	window.captchaComplete = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = true;
		if ($(mail).val() != '' && isEmail($(mail).val())) {
			$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
		}
		setTimeout(function() {
			$(email).focus();
			$('.g-recaptcha iframe').attr('tabindex', '-1');
		}, 100)
	}
	window.captchaExpires = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = false;
		$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
	} 
	$(subscription_form).submit(function(e) {
		e.preventDefault();
		e.stopImmediatePropagation();
		updateEmailMask();
		var success = true;
		var form = $(this);
		var mail = form.find('input[name="Email"]');
		
		if (mail.val() === '') {
			mail.addClass('has-error');
			showError(1);
			success = false;	
		}  else if (!isEmail(mail.val())){
			showError(2);
			success = false;
		}
		else {
			mail.removeClass('has-error');
			$('.error-mail').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (!subscribeSuccess) {
			$('.error-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
		} else {
			$('.error-recaptcha').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (success && subscribeSuccess) {
			$.ajax({
				type: 'POST',
				url: form.attr('action'),
				data: form.serialize(),
				beforeSend: function() {
                 form.find('button').addClass('is-loading');
    			},
				success: function(msg) {
					form.find('.form-success-message').html('<p class="success-message">You have been successfully subscribed</p>');
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					$(email).val('');
					clearError();
				},
				error: function(jqXHR, textStatus, errorThrown) {
					$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					
				}
			});
		}
		return false;
	});
	function showError(error_type){
		if(error_type == 1) {
			$('.error-mail').text("Please enter the email address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		} else if(error_type == 2){
			$('.error-mail').text("Please provide a valid e-mail address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		}	
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
	}
	function clearError(){
		$('.error-mail').text("").removeClass('error-show');;
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
	}
	
	$(email).on('input', function (event) { 
		var email = $(this).val();
		if (isEmail(email) ) {			
			clearError();
		} else if(email == ""){
			clearError();
		} else{
			showError(2);			  
		}
    });

	function isEmail(email) {
		var re = /^(([^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+(\.[^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+)*)|(".+"))@((\[[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\])|(([a-zA-Z\-0-9]+\.)+[a-zA-Z]{2,}))$/;
		return re.test(String(email).toLowerCase());
	}
	
	var captcha_loaded = false;
         if(!captcha_loaded){
            // recaptcha on foucs call
            $(document).on('change paste keyup', '#newsletter-email', function () {
               if($('.g-recaptcha').hasClass('d-none')){
                $('.g-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
               }
               if(!captcha_loaded ){
                  captcha_loaded  = true;
                  // trigger loading api.js (recaptcha.js) script
                  var head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
                  var script = document.createElement('script');
                  script.type = 'text/javascript';
                  script.src = 'https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js?hl=en_US';
                  head.appendChild(script);
               }
            });
        }
	
	function updateEmailMask() {
		var email = $("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='Email']").val();
		if (email && email.trim() != '') {
			var maskedEmail = maskEmailAddress(email);
			$("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='emailFormMask']").val(maskedEmail);
		}
	}

	function maskEmailAddress (emailAddress) {
		function mask(str) {
			var strLen = str.length;
			if (strLen > 4) {
				return str.substr(0, 1) + str.substr(1, strLen - 1).replace(/\w/g, '*') + str.substr(-1,1);
			}
			return str.replace(/\w/g, '*');
		}
		return emailAddress.replace(/([\w.]+)@([\w.]+)(\.[\w.]+)/g, function (m, p1, p2, p3) {
			return mask(p1) + '@' + mask(p2) + p3;
		});

		return emailAddress;
	}

}(jQuery));
//# sourceMappingURL=main.js.map
	
</script>
<!--  End: Footer subscription form -->

						</li>    
					        
					</ul>
				</nav>
						            </div>
            <div class="nav-column">
              													<nav>
					<ul class="footer-menu-nav__list"> 
																	<li class="footer-menu-nav__item nav-title"> 
							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42"   role="link" title="Threat Intel and Incident Response Services" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Products and services:Threat Intel and Incident Response Services">Threat Intel and Incident Response Services</a>
						</li>    
																	<li class="footer-menu-nav__item "> 
							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42/assess"   role="link" title="Proactive Assessments" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Products and services:Threat Intel and Incident Response Services:Proactive Assessments">Proactive Assessments</a>
						</li>    
																	<li class="footer-menu-nav__item "> 
							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42/respond"   role="link" title="Incident Response" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Products and services:Threat Intel and Incident Response Services:Proactive Assessments:Incident Response">Incident Response</a>

    <script type="text/javascript">
	var isProcessing = false; 
    function alter_ul_post_values(obj,post_id,ul_type){
	
		if (isProcessing)    
		return;  
		isProcessing = true;   
		var like_nonce = jQuery('#_wpnonce').val();
		jQuery(obj).find("span").html("..");
                jQuery.ajax({
                    type: "POST",
                    url: "https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/like-dislike-counter-for-posts-pages-and-comments/ajax_counter.php",
                    data: "post_id="+post_id+"&up_type="+ul_type+"&ul_nonce="+like_nonce,
                    success: function(msg){
                            jQuery(obj).find("span").html(msg);
                            isProcessing = false; 
                            jQuery(obj).find('svg').children('path').attr('stroke','#0050FF');
                            jQuery(obj).removeClass('idc_ul_cont_not_liked idc_ul_cont_not_liked_inner');
                    }
 		});
	}
	</script>
    <link rel='stylesheet' id='wpdevart_lightbox_front_end_css-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/lightbox-popup/includes/style/wpdevart_lightbox_front.css?ver=6.6.1' media='all' />
<script src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/js/script.js?ver=1.0.0" id="unit42-v6-navigation-js"></script>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
observer_lozad.observe();

window.PAN_Clean_Util = {
        isIE: false
};

(function () {
   // INP Util Fix
    function yieldToMain(ms) {
        return new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, ms));
    }
   window.PAN_Clean_Util.yieldToMain = yieldToMain
})();

if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
  var Coveo_organizationId = "paloaltonetworksintranet";        
  var techDocsPagePath = "https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/search.html#hd=All%20Prisma%20Cloud%20Documentation&hq=%40panproductcategory%3D%3D(%22Prisma%20Cloud%22)&sort=relevancy&layout=card&numberOfResults=25";
  var languageFromPath="en_US";
  window.Granite = window.Granite || {};
  Granite.I18n = (function() {
  var self = {};
  self.setLocale = function(locale) { };
  self.get = function(text, snippets, note) {
    var out = "";
    if(text){
      if(text ==="coveo.clear"){
        out = "Clear";
      }else if(text ==="coveo.noresultsfound"){
        out = "No results found for this search term.";
      }
    }
    return out;
  };
  return self
  }());
}

  var main_site_critical_top = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTop.min.js';
  var main_site_defered = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/defered.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopBase = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopBase.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopProductNav = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopProductNav.min.js';
window.PAN_MainNavAsyncUrl = maindomain_lang+"/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html";

function loadScript(url, defer){
    var script1 = document.createElement('script');
    script1.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript');
    script1.setAttribute('src',url);
    if(defer == true){
        script1.setAttribute('defer','defer');
    }
    document.head.appendChild(script1);
}
function loadScript1(url, callback){

    var script = document.createElement("script")
    script.type = "text/javascript";
    if (script.readyState){  //IE
        script.onreadystatechange = function(){
            if (script.readyState == "loaded" || script.readyState == "complete"){
                script.onreadystatechange = null;
                callback();
            }
        };
    } else {  //Others
        script.onload = function(){
            callback();
        };
    }
    script.src = url;
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);
}
if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
	if(referer == "Unit"){
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript(main_site_criticalTopBase, false);
      loadScript1(main_site_criticalTopProductNav, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
	else{
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript1(main_site_critical_top, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
}

$(document).ready(function () {
    setTimeout(function(){
      $('.article-banner .ab__options ul li a').each(function(){
          	$(this).attr('target', "_blank");
      });
    }, 4000);
});
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

</body>
</html>
